title: Data Mining for Next Generation Transportation Systems
segmentation: Thank you Lisa and hello, that was a very good introduction to some of the things I'm going to be talking about.
It's really encouraging for me to see that.
There is so much commonality between what you were talking about and hopefully what I'm going to present today.
So with that I'll introduce myself.
My name is Ashok Srivastava and I am going to be talking to you about work that's going on at NASA in the area of vehicle health management.
And So what we're talking about.
There is primarily aircraft, so commercial aircraft that we all fly around on and trying to understand in this context about the health of those aircraft, in other words.
Are they operating according to what you would expect?
And I'm really going to focus a little bit on that last phrase there.
What do you expect when you're flying on an aircraft as far as fuel usage goes, and field performance goes, so I'll talk to you a little bit about that.
I'll also talk to you about how data mining and machine learning can play a role in understanding and studying some of these systems, so it's a very timely topic because.
Of some of the following reasons here.
The notion of green aviation has come up a number of times at the national level as a priority for the United States to invest in to develop clean technologies for for running aviation systems.
And you can see some of the challenges that we're facing here.
So in 2008, the US commercial carriers alone burned about 20 billion gallons of jet fuel.
Think about it, 20 billions of gallons of jet fuel DoD itself burned about 5 billion gallons of jet fuel at an average price of $3.
That's a lot of money.
73 billion dollars just on jet fuel, not to account for the infrastructure that Hill was mentioning, just to support the aircraft that's just during flight.

On top of that, think about the emissions so 40 out of the 50 US airports are in a nonattainment areas that don't meet local EPA air quality standards, and some of us might actually live in those cities and and bear the consequences of those emissions.

And this is a serious issue, and I know that there are a lot of parties that are involved in monitoring this and ensuring compliance, and we're also trying to work in order to make engines and aircraft.
So that they don't emit and burn as much fuel, 1/3 area which we didn't discuss so far, but is important in the aviation industry is the note is noise.

So if you live near an airport or if you've ever been near one, you know that there is a noise issue and sometimes that noise can be extremely detrimental to the people and the the local area around the airports, and so this is another third characteristic that now says focusing on so it's.
It's about fuel.
It's about emissions and it's about noise.
And so what's happening?
And I'll describe this to you in a moment.
Is there's a research program called environmentally Responsible Aviation which is getting set up right now to address these three topics, and I'll tell you a little bit more about that.
But before I go into it, I'd really like to discuss with you.
How at least we're envisioning data mining and machine learning could play a role in this area, because I think it can play a critical role, as as Lisa was pointing out.
So if you think about what's required here we I think we would all agree vigorously that there's a lot of data available and it's multi modality.
It's sampled at different rates and so forth, so all kinds of interesting algorithms and problems come to mind immediately when you hear things like that, right?
But the.

Key issue is that we're not just mining it and then presenting a paper or mining it, and then giving a talk about it instead of what we're trying to do is modify behavior on a huge scale across the aviation system.

If you can imagine modify behavior based on data that is available, so a transition that needs to be made from data is knowledge Discovery, another we need to be able to build systems that harvest harvest information out of those data systems and put it into a decision support.
Framework so that in one case humans can actually read it and make a decision.

Make predictions, but in another case have automated systems make those decisions and I think you were pointing that out in your discussion as well, that the system adaptation at the bottom of the chart here is really critical that in some cases if you have a system that is monitoring, let's say the fuel usage in an aircraft, you may actually want it to automatically make a change in the aircraft's behavior in its state in such a way that it reduces the fuel consumption.
Now for cars and for other sorts of systems, there is probably.
Certain strategies that can be employed in the aviation domain.
It becomes one or two levels more complex because there's this notion of certification and verification and validation of this system.
So when we talk about system adaptation there, that's a hugely loaded phrase for those people who are in the aviation industry.
What that really means is discussion negotiation with the FAA and with other bodies in order to prove that this adaptive system that we have developed.
Although it might be simple, is safe and is not going to go into some failed state during flight, so that system adaptation for aviation systems becomes an extremely difficult task.

In fact, to give you an idea, the notion of verification and validation of these sorts of systems in general for flight critical systems and NASA has been has been brought to bear to the tune of about 100 million dollars invested over the next five years simply to study.
That one problem domain.
So this is a critical area.
Once there is some adaptation though, one could take some automated action or some combination of human action as well as machine action in order to mitigate the issue that you're facing.
So what happens is that massive data has to come in to enable some sort of real time decisions, and we can discuss what real time means.
Real time might mean in the moment, as the plane is flying, make a decision.
It might actually mean.
Sending information down to logistics into supply chain.
Personnel saying the aircraft has an issue.
It's not imminent.
We're going to land and then take some decisions.
Maybe change something.
And the configuration of the aircraft in order to improve efficiency or improve its safety profile.
So those are some of the challenges that we're facing in this area.
Now again, Lisa touched on an important idea, at least in our domain.
Also of trying to marry physics, which is the way the aviation community understandably views their system and data.
Mining, data analysis and machine learning, which is what a lot of us do here.
These are very important, not necessarily parallel paths.
They do have some overlaps in them, and it's something that's very important to explore, so let's just look at this equation.
If you open up a textbook.

On fuel consumption on aircraft, if you were to look at this, you'll see a formula that looks like this, which is based on physics, which tells you how to calculate the range of an aircraft given information about the fuel consumption of the aircraft.
Given aerodynamics, the empty weight, etc.

And so you plug it into the formula you get, arrange out, which makes perfect sense, but if you think about it from our standpoint, as people in the data analysis field, what this really is is it's an unconditional distribution, or at best it's conditioned on some.
Pretty broad.
Quantities like the empty weight of the aircraft, the aerodynamics and so forth.
It's not really talking about instantaneously, as the airplane is flying under this particular configuration.
With this rigging with this.
The amount of weight on the aircraft would this altitude.
What is the fuel consumption?
That's a different question than what this sort of formula gives you.
This formula gives you kind of an average case.
It gives you an unconditional distribution or at least conditioned on some pretty broad variables.
So one thing that we're interested in doing is changing that.
So instead of looking at unconditional distributions or distributions that are conditioned on some pretty broad pieces of information.

What if you could take the data and actually analyze it on a 1 Hertz level, which is the data rate that sampled an aircraft and say in the last second based on the data that based on the state of the aircraft.
What was the fuel consumption?
Let's say a burned.
10 pounds of fuel in the last second.
Well, is that 10 pounds good or bad?
Is that a lot or is it little given the state of the aircraft?
That's a very different question.
And this is the direction that we're headed right now.
So rather than than computing.
The quantity.
Probability of the total fuel given something.
What we're trying to do is say what's the probability of the fuel usage at time T, where T is right now, given the aircraft state at time T. What's what's that?
What does that distribution look like?
And if that distribution is such that it's very narrow and you're well within the expected distribution, you can say my aircraft for the last second was operating.
As we should expect, because it's within the distribution, that's.
Characterizing expected behavior.
But what happens if the fuel consumption is actually outside for the last second of this distribution?
You might say, well, let's ignore it for now.

Maybe it'll become better, but if you again and again past many sequences of flights, see that your aircraft, given the state of the aircraft, is operating in such a way that it's using more aircraft, more aircraft fuel than expected, then you know that there's something different, and that's really an computation that's being done on a conditional distribution.
As opposed to unconditional and this is a key difference.
I talk to a lot of people in the airlines and they say the way we do it is we look essentially at a histogram of flights.
Let's say this is.
This chart is showing fuel consumption between New York and Los Angeles flights on a Boeing 737, and that's what the fuel consumption looks like.
And So what you do is, you would say, if if my flight.
Was over here at 2.
You'd say, well, it used more than the average, and so maybe there was something wrong.
Will we're going to track it?
And maybe if it was at minus two, you'd say, well, that was it.
That was actually a good flight.

Maybe the weight distribution was good and and so forth, and so we got to get a little bit more mileage out of the aircraft at that time, but that's a very different question than what we're trying to address here.
What we're trying to say is during the flight, how much was consumed, and so we're going down this path of studying the conditional distribution that I described.
And we're in the process of validating it with a major US carrier, and we're hoping that we're going to see that there.
Some success, so now I'm quickly going to step through a program that I mentioned earlier called environmentally responsible Aviation.
This is being led by a colleague of mine, Fay Collier, who is.
Running a program to essentially reduce emissions, noise and fuel burn on aircraft by a significant amount by 2020.
So this is benchmarks that we're setting that could have a data mining in a machine learning component to it right now.
Frankly, they're thinking about physics.
They're taking about thinking about aerodynamics about machinery on the aircraft, optimizing it to make these to make these improvements.
But we're talking about a 42 decibel.
Reduction in noise by twenty 2075% reduction of landing and takeoff, NOx emissions, etc.
You can see here that this is a pretty aggressive schedule that they're putting forward, and there may be a data mining and machine learning component to it.
I can't vouch for that.
That's something that Faye and others are going to are going.
To address in here on this chart, you can see what the NASA goal is here.
Reduction essentially.
And NOx emissions compared to what is going on right now.

So finally, if you're interested in this sort of technologies and health management in the way emissions and other things can influence the earth Sciences and so forth, I'd like to just let you know that we're having a conference called the Conference on Intelligent Data Understanding it's October 5 through 7 in Mountain View, CA.
Registration is free, hence the nice green check mark at the bottom of the chart, and you're welcome to come and participate and and listen to people from.
The data mining community as well as from the other communities of the Earth Sciences of the aeronautical industry, come and talk about some of these sorts of problems in the challenges.
We're very fortunate to have a very distinguished steering committee here.

Many of the members are here at KDD right now, and frankly, many of these members are some of the founders of this conference, and so I'm very well very fortunate to have them on our steering committee.
Notice Charla and Phillip unit dishes.
Here is the program chair.
And if you're interested in hearing more about these sorts of issues, I'd welcome your participation at that conference.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Gene.
